qas.question: How many groups do these languages belong to?
What are the three Insular Celtic languages?
What are the remaining Cetic languages that are still used today?
Which cant is often used by Irish Travellers?
In 1980, what happened to the Norn language of Orkney and Shetland?
Where are the Norman languages, similar to German, spoken?
Which language of Gaelic and Shetland became extinct in 1880?
The Insular Travellers languages of the Goidelic subgroup, along with what other sub group are the only Celtic languages remaining?

context: The linguistic heritage of the British Isles is rich, with twelve languages from <a0_0>six groups<a0_0/> across four branches of the Indo-European family. The Insular Celtic languages of the Goidelic sub-group (<a1_0>Irish, Manx and Scottish Gaelic<a1_0/>) and the <b7_0>Brittonic sub-group<b7_0/> (<a2_0>Cornish, Welsh and Breton<a2_0/>, spoken in north-western France) are the only remaining Celtic languages—the last of their continental relations becoming extinct before the 7th century. The Norman languages of Guernésiais, Jèrriais and Sarkese spoken in the <b5_0>Channel Islands<b5_0/> are similar to French. A cant, called <a3_0>Shelta<a3_0/>, is spoken by Irish Travellers, often as a means to conceal meaning from those outside the group. However, English, sometimes in the form of Scots, is the dominant language, with few monoglots remaining in the other languages of the region. The <b6_0>Norn language<b6_0/> of Orkney and Shetland <b4_0>became extinct<b4_0/> around 1880.
